Generally, an instrument for measuring low current, an ammeter with a scale which indicates current in picoamperes. This one was used with the photoelectric photometers of a telescope at an astronomical observatory.

One of a group of instruments used in the DDO Electronic Shop for calibration and testing of the Observatory's observational instruments. This one was used with photoelectric photometers at the telescope. It has a Keithley Input Head model 4160. Note this is identical to the one used with the St.Mary's University / Fernie photometer which was acquired by SMU in 1972. Range: 10(-5) to 10(-12) amps (picoamp range). This type of picoammeter is useful for high-speed measurements of low-level currents generated by high-impedance sources such as photo-multipliers, high-speed mass spectrometers, ion chambers, ans flame and beta-ray ionization detectors. Other applications include transient current measurements, noise studies and flash filament testing. This example is identical to the Keithley model 417 picoammeter (2008.0208) except that the 417 provides a suppression current at the input up to 1000 times full scale on most ranges (Ref. 2).
This example: the David Dunlop Observatory in Richmond Hill, ON

An epidiascope is a device used to project images of both opaque and transparent images, typically used to project images of book pages, drawings, mineral specimens, leaves, etc.

An example of a large epidiascope. This device was used to show mounted glass slides in lectures and colloquia. A book or diagram could be placed in the opening on the side to project that as well. The hammertone finish of this instrument suggests a date of manufacture of circa 1955 to 1970. This device displays opaque materials by shining a bright lamp onto the object from above. A system of mirrors, prisms and/or imaging lenses is used to focus an image of the material onto a viewing screen. Because they must project the reflected light, opaque projectors require brighter bulbs and larger lenses than overhead projectors and so generate more heat than an overhead projector.
This example: the David Dunlop Observatory in Richmond Hill, ON

Miscellaneous instruments & equipment;:;Instruments et équipement divers
A precision measuring device used at the Dominion Observatory, Ottawa (c. 1905-1970). This spherometer may have been used on a variety of astronomy, survey or metrology instruments employed there.

A spherometer is a type of micrometer that measures the radius of a sphere. It is commonly used in optics to determine the curvature lenses. The instrument is placed on ant part of a mirror or lens and the central micrometric screw is turned carefully until it just touches the lens or mirror surface. The measurement is the reading on the vernier scale. This instrument was designed to measure small spherical curvatures. (Taken from the worksheet)
Silver-coloured metal with some copper-coloured parts.

Double Astrograph Manufacturer: John A. Brashear Company Limited, Pittsburgh, PA ca. 1914B1915 Artifact no. 1966.0401 Source: Dominion Observatory
To supplement the main 15-inch telescope, in 1915 the Dominion Observatory acquired this camera-telescope, which could photograph large areas of sky and also capture the spectra of brighter stars in the same field of view. A thin wedge-shaped optical element on the longer tube created the spectra on a separate photographic plate.
Astrographe double Fabricant : John A. Brashear Company Limited, Pittsburgh (Pennsylvanie) vers 1914-1915 No d'artefact : 1966.0401 Source : Observatoire fédéral
En 1915, en plus de sa lunette principale de 15 p. de diamètre, l'Observatoire fédéral acquiert cette deuxième lunette capable de photographier de grandes portions de ciel tout en captant le spectre des étoiles les plus brillantes dans le même champ de vision. Un mince élément optique en forme de coin posé sur le tube le plus long étale le spectre sur une plaque photographique.

Coelostat Manufacturer: John A. Brashear Company Limited, Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania 1904B1905 Artifact no. 1966.0402 Source: Dominion Observatory
This specialized telescope was used specifically for solar observations. Its three mirrors focussed sunlight onto a spectrograph which captured a Aspectrum@ of the sunlight on a photograph. First used in Labrador to research the total solar eclipse of 1905, it became Canada=s primary instrument for studying the Sun.
Expédition de 1905 au Labrador
Coelostat Fabricant : John A. Brashear Company Limited, Pittsburgh (Pennsylvanie) 1904-1905 No d'artefact : 1966.0402 Source : Observatoire fédéral
Ce télescope spécialisé a servi exclusivement à l'observation du Soleil. Ses trois miroirs permettent de diriger les rayons solaires sur un spectrographe qui, lui, enregistre les raies spectrales sur une plaque photographique. Utilisé pour la première fois au Labrador à l'occasion de recherches menées sur l'éclipse solaire totale de 1905, il devient le principal instrument employé au Canada pour l'étude du Soleil.

BRITISH MADE INSTRUMENT USED IN CANADA, POSSIBLY AT DOMINION OBSERVATORY IN OTTAWA, WHICH EXISTED FROM 1905 TO 1970 (RCB 13.9.96)

INSTRUMENT USED TO RECORD TIME DURATION OF ASTRONOMICAL EVENTS. IT RECEIVED TWO TIME SIGNALS WHICH WERE RECORDED ON PAPER COVERED DRUM. ONE PEN RECORDED TIME EACH SECOND FROM STANDARD CLOCK & SECOND PEN WAS ACTUATED BY TAPPING OF KEY BY OBSERVER OF EVENT BEING TIMED. THIS EXAMPLE WAS PROBABLY USED WITH TRANSIT TELESCOPE: ONE SIGNAL CAME FROM CLOCK, OTHER FROM OBSERVER WATCHING STARS.

BRITISH MAKER NALDER BROS. FL. AT 16 RED LION ST., CLERKENWELL, LONDON, E.C. IN 1894/ CHRONOGRAPH WAS DEVELOPED BETWEEN 1828 & 1850 IN GERMANY & U.S. PRIMARILY TO REDUCE INDIVIDUAL DIFFERENCES IN PERCEPTION OF TIME WHICH DISTORTED ASTRONOMICAL OBSERVATIONS. IT WAS ALSO USED IN SEISMOLOGY & IN OTHER AREAS.

PRECISION MEASURING DEVICE USED AT DOMINION OBSERVATORY, OTTAWA (C.1905-1970). THIS SPHEROMETER MAY HAVE BEEN USED ON A VARIETY OF ASTRONOMY, SURVEYAND/OR METROLOGY INSTRUMENTS EMPLOYED THERE. PRESUMABLY IT WAS ALSO USED BY NRC, FROM WHOM THE MUSEUM ACQUIRED THIS SPHEROMETER.

TO MEASURE THE CURVATURE OF SOLID SPHERICAL SURFACES, EITHER CONVEX OR CONCAVE. IT IS USED TO MEASURE THE INEQUALITY OF PIVOTS (POSTS OR TRUNNIONS ON WHICH A VARIETY OF SCIENTIFIC INSTRUMENTS REST), AND TO MEASURE THE CURVATURE OF LENSES.

MORE RELIABLE & EASIER TO USE THAN A CONTACT LEVEL, THE SPHEROMETER IS AN EXTREMELY ACCURATE MEASURING INSTRUMENT. WEAR OF MOUNTINGS ON A VARIETY OF SCIENTIFIC INSTRUMENTS (IE. TRANSITS, THEODOLITES, LEVELS, TELESCOPES, ETC.) WILL PRODUCE ERRORS IN READINGS: THESE INSTRUMENTS MUST BE CHECKED REGULARLY FOR SUCH WEAR * CONT
AFTER C. 1885. DOMINION OBSERVATORY OPERATED C. 1905-1970. NRC MAY HAVE USED THE SPHEROMETER FOLLOWING 1970

INTRODUCED IN 1954, THE QUESTAR WAS A SMALL TABLETOP OR PORTABLE TELESCOPE WITH MAKSUTOV CASSEGRAIN CATADIOPTRIC OPTICS. IT WAS MARKETED FOR USE BY ASTRONOMERS, NATURALISTS, PHOTOGRAPHERS, ETC. IN ADDITION TO THIS 3.5 INCH APERTURE MODEL, THERE WAS ALSO THE QUESTAR SEVEN, WITH A 7 INCH APERTURE (REF. 2).

PLATED METAL TELESCOPE BASE & PARTS/ BLUE SYNTHETIC COVERED BARREL & DEWCAP/ BLACK ENAMELLED PARTS & EYEPIECE HOUSINGS/ RED ENAMELLED DISKS ON BASE, SIDES, & LENS COVER/ CLEAR SYNTHETIC AZIMUTH MARKER/ WHITE & BLUE AZIMUTH ON BASE/ BROWN LEATHER CASE/ BROWN LUGGAGE COVER/ FLAT BLACK PAINTED SOLAR FILTER HOUSING

NO. BREAKDOWN:.1 TELESCOPE,.2 80-160X EYEPIECE (ON TELESCOPE),.3 40-80X EYEPIECE,.4 DEWCAP,.5-.7 LEGS,.8-.9 SCREWS,.10 POWER CORD,.11 SOLAR FILTER/ CW. BARREL PROTECTOR & LENS CAP, CARRYING CASE & LUGGAGE COVER/ DIM: GIVEN ARE FOR CASE WITH COVER;.1 D-18, H-35.4;.11 D-13.7, H-6.2/ ACQUIRED FOR USE IN NMST OBSERVATORY/ *PREVIOUS NMST NOS: (.11 SOLAR FILTER) SP0042
1) 'QUESTAR INSTRUCTION BOOK', QUESTAR CORP., NEW HOPE, PA., ND
5) MUSEUM DOCUMENTATION, PHOTOS, ETC. IN SUPP. INFO.

TELESCOPE USED AT DOMINION OBSERVATORY, CANADA'S PREDOMINANT ASTRONOMICAL OBSERVATORY WHICH OPERATED FROM 1905 TO 1970. IT WAS ONE OF TWO PURCHASED C. 1958-1959 (OTHER WENT C. 1968 TO PHYSICS DEPT. OF U. OF WATERLOO, WHERE IT IS STILL IN USE) & WAS USED FOR PUBLIC VIEWING.
INSTRUMENT USED TO VIEW CELESTIAL OBJECTS. THIS TELESCOPE WAS USED BY DOMINION OBSERVATORY TO GIVE DEMONSTRATIONS TO GENERAL PUBLIC.

EXAMPLE OF 12 INCH REFLECTING TELESCOPE WITH PARABOLIC F/15 PRIMARY MIRROR & HYPERBOLIC SECONDARY, OF POOR QUALITY, ESPECIALLY SECONDARY (REF. 1). TINSLEY WAS ONE OF LARGEST MFRS. OF SMALL TO MID-SIZED PROFESSIONAL (OR LARGE AMATEUR) TELESCOPES FROM AROUND 1939 INTO 1970S.
USED AT THE DOMINION OBSERVATORY IN OTTAWA, IN ROLL-OFF ROOF BUILDING NEXT TO MAIN BUILDING.
PAINTED SMOOTH LIGHT GREY & TEXTURED DARKER GREY FINISH WITH BLACK & SILVER-COLOURED PTS

Miscellaneous instruments & equipment;:;Instruments et équipement divers

Housed a precision measuring device used at the Dominion Observatory, Ottawa (c. 1905-1970). This spherometer may have been used on a variety of astronomy, survey or metrology instruments employed there.
To store and protect a spherometer.
Medium brown wood with a slightly darker finish and a green cloth covered piece at the bottom on the inside.
No. breakdown: .1 spherometer; .2 base; .3 box; .4 lid, box
CSTMC Acquisition Worksheet prepared by M. Labrecque
Measuring the Radius of Curvature by Means of a Spherometer, http://online.physics.uiuc.edu/courses/phys402/exp/Sph/SPH.pdf (in Supp. Info file 2012.0084)
Wood body; fabric lining; synthetic label
Optical telescope parts & accessories;:;Pièces et accessoires de télescope optique

Thomas Pocklington Ltd. made and repaired surveying instruments in Toronto between 1925 and 1992. It was one of the few Canadian firms producing precision instruments before WWII. Thomas (b. 1882), the founder, was trained as an instrument maker in the U.K. He moved to Toronto in the early 20th century and worked for Consolidated Optical Co. until he started his own business in 1925. From that time until 1940 the firm occupied a location near what is now the Eaton centre; from 1940 to 1953 the firm occupied 30 Bridgman Ave (presently Tarragon Theatre); from 1953 to 1992 they occupied 208 Weston Rd. The CSTM has the Brightly circular dividing engine (CSTM ARTIFACT # 1992.1776) purchased by the firm in 1940. Thomas was succeeded by his son William, who was succeeded by his two sons John and Ronald.
Very little is known about the small precision instrument industry in Toronto in the late 19th and early 20th century. Our growing collection of archival material and artifacts related to Pocklington, one of the leaders in that community, provides a more complete picture of this history. (Taken directly from acquisition proposal)
An instrument for measuring small distances in the field of an eyepiece.
Instruments like this one document important phases in the history of this firm. This device represents the firm's involvement in WWII.
Black metal body with brass and silver-coloured metal knobs.

No. breakdown: .1 micrometer; .2 eyepiece Part of a group of objects from Thomas Pocklington of Thos. Pocklington Ltd. There are no markings indicating the maker anywhere on the object, but it is assumed to be made by this company (according to the proposal) Dim. given include the eyepiece, which is attached to the main unit but may be removed.
Acquisition Proposal prepared by DAP in Supp. Info. file 2007.0264
Volume III of "Men and Meridians" (our HA for surveying)
Randall Brooks, "A Conversation with and Instrument Maker," Rittenhouse, to be published 2007.
Randall Brooks, "The Brightly Circular Dividing Engine," Rittenhouse, 11, (1997), 75-80.
Van Nostrand's Scientific Encyclopedia, Third Ed. "Filar Micrometer." Princeton: D. Van Nostrand Company, Inc., 1958.

Deterioration Notes: Artifact is in fair to good condition. Light surface dust and dirty accretions overall. There are some small nicks, scratches, and areas of abrasion on wooden surfaces. Paper on top and bottom of wood base and covering globe is soiled and discoloured with some abrasion, lifting, and loss of material. There is a large split in the wood substrate of the world globe which has also damaged the paper in this area. Copper alloy components have oxidized and there is one spot of black and reddish-purple copper corrosion on the large brass washer.

Metal cabinet. Metal slide racks. Plastic light diffusion screen with metal frame.
NO KNOWN DIRECT ASSOCIATION TO OR SPECIFIC USE IN CANADA.
TO OBSERVE THE CELESTIAL SKY; PROVIDES AN ERECT IMAGE AND THUS CAN BE USED FOR VIEWING LAND AS WELL; SMALL AND EASY TO MANAGE.
TYPICAL REFLECTING TELESCOPE OF THE PERIOD, USING A METAL SPECULUM; USED OFTEN AS A TABLETOP TELESCOPE IN THE 18TH CENTURY.
BRASS COLOURED FINISH/ STAND PAINTED BROWN

Gregorian Reflecting Telescope
MAKER James Hurt
WHEN ca 1736 to 1748
WHAT DOES IT DO? Magnifies astronomical objects for study.
HOW DOES IT WORK? Two concave mirrors are used to magnify objects. It produced better images than refracting telescope (which use lenses).
Telescope a Reflecteur de Type Gregorian
FABRICANT James Hurt
DATE entre 1736 et 1748
QUOI ÇA SERT? Grossit les astres en vue de les observer.
COMMENT ÇA MARCHE? Deux miroirs concaves servent à grossir les objets observés. Les images étaient plus nettes que celles obtenues avec le télescope à réfracteur (qui utilise des lentilles).

VALUE: IN GBP/ AUCTION LOT: 90, OCT 21 1982 SALE/ GREGORIAN REFLECTING TELESCOPE WITH 2 MIRRORS OF CAST SPECULUM METAL & HUYGENIAN EYEPIECE. FOCAL LENGTH 1.52M., MAGNIFICATION 25X./ IN THE 17TH CENTURY, SEVERAL TYPES OF REFLECTING TELESCOPES WERE SUGGESTED. IN 1663 JAMES GREGORY PUBLISHED A DESIGN FOR THE GREGORIAN REFLECTING TELESCOPE. HOWEVER REFLECTING TELESCOPES DID NOT COME INTO GENERAL USE UNTIL THE 2ND & 3RD DECADES OF THE 18TH CENTURY DUE TO PRACTICAL DIFFICULTIES IN MAKING GOOD MIRRORS, AFTER WHICH MANY WERE MANUFACTURED. THE REFLECTING TELESCOPE GRADUALLY DROPPED OUT OF USE DURING THE FIRST HALF OF THE 19TH CENTURY, REPLACED BY THE REFRACTING TELESCOPE WITH ITS ACHROMATIC LENS INVENTED IN 1729 (WYNTER & TURNER, PP.187-202). SEE ILLUSTRATIONS OF SIMILAR SPECIMENS IN WYNTER & TURNER, PP. 195, 196/ THE GREGORIAN TELESCOPE HAS A SHORT TUBE, PRIMARY MIRROR WITH A HOLE; THE SECONDARY MIRROR IS CONCAVE & A SECTION OF AN ELLIPSOID, & PERPENDICULAR TO THE OPTICAL AXIS. UNLIKE OTHER ASTRONOMICAL INSTRUMENTS, IT PROVIDES AN ERECT IMAGE & CAN BE USED FOR VIEWING LAND OBJECTS. IN THE 18TH CENTURY, IT WAS OFTEN USED A TABLETOP TELESCOPE, DESPITE ITS SMALL FIELD OF VIEW (LOVI, P.12)
Black & white negative;:;Négatif noir et blanc
1) LOVI, G. 'THE TELESCOPE CATALOG OF CATALOGUES', 1979, PP.5-20 [QB 88 L68 NMST]
2) WYNTER, H. & TURNER, A. 'SCIENTIFIC INSTRUMENTS', 1975, PP.187-202 [Q185 W98 1975B NMST]
3) NOTE FROM R. BROOKS RE MFG DATE (AUG 23 2002), IN S.I.
4) Museum Documents, Additional Material & Photos in Supp. Info.

AN AMERICAN MADE TELESCOPE USED BY THE DOMINION OBSERVATORY IN OTTAWA, & LATER BY NMST AS PART OF ITS ASTRONOMICAL EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMME.

AN OPTICAL INSTRUMENT WHICH PROVIDED A DISTINCT, MAGNIFIED IMAGE OF DISTANT OBJECTS FOR ASTRONOMY & NATURE STUDY AND OBSERVATIONS. THIS TELESCOPE WAS PRIMARILY AN ASTRONOMICAL OBSERVING INSTRUMENT, & COULD SERVE AS THE TELESCOPIC LENS OF A CAMERA FOR STILL OR CINEMA PHOTOGRAPHY.

INTRODUCED IN 1954, THE QUESTAR WAS A SMALL TABLETOP OR PORTABLE TELESCOPE WITH MAKSUTOV CASSEGRAIN CATADIOPTRIC OPTICS. IT WAS MARKETED FOR USE BY ASTRONOMERS, NATURALISTS, PHOTOGRAPHERS, ETC. IN ADDITION TO THIS 3.5 INCH APERTURE MODEL, THERE WAS ALSO THE QUESTAR SEVEN, WITH A 7 INCH APERTURE (REF. 2).

EQUIPMENT USED AT ALGONQUIN RADIO OBSERVATORY. ARO WAS ESTABLISHED IN LATE 1950S TO PROVIDE NATIONAL RADIO OBSERVATORY PROVIDING FACILITIES TO CONTINUE TO MONITOR SUN IN COLLABORATION WITH DOMINION RADIO ASTROPHYSICAL OBSERVATORY (DRAO) ESTABLISHED IN 1957 IN PENTICTON BC.
DEVICE ATTACHED TO ASTRONOMICAL PARABOLIC ANTENNA IN ORDER TO VERIFY & CALIBRATE IT. LOAD PROVIDED SOURCE SIGNAL TO CHECK THAT WAVE GUIDES, FILTERS, POLARIZERS & ELECTRONICS WERE OPERATING PROPERLY.

CALIBRATION DEVICE USED WITH ARO ANTENNA ARRAY. ARRAY COMBINED SIGNALS FROM 245 ANTENNAA THROUGH PARALLEL WAVEGUIDES WHICH WERE COMBINED NEARELECTRONICS. SIGNALS WOULD HAVE TO BE CHECKED TO ENSURE THEY WERE IN PHASE SO THAT OUT OF PHASE SIGNALS FROM SUN WOULD BE DETECTED & RECORDED PROPERLY.

Radio telescope parts & accessories;:;Pièces et accessoires de radiotélescope
Used for Canadian radio astronomy research at the National Research Council of Canada.

Used to measure low levels of AC current in microamperes, over a range of 20 to 6000 Hz. For instance, atmospheric noise and/or radio frequency magnetic waves generated by stars and amplified to a level that could be measured by this meter.
British-made permanent magnet moving coil type AC portable microammeter. This moving coil instrument uses a rectifier to convert the AC current into DC current which it can measure.
Meter glass, to be reset. Meter defective. May be defective instrument rectifier. From CA of 01/09/2002 by David Daley: No - Complete
Glossy black bakelite case; silver coloured meter face with black calibration.

Two painted spots, one orange and the other cream-coloured, on the back of the meter. The balancing of the movement is done by twisting the balancing arm into a coil. This is an uncommon method for meters. It is cheap and probably inaccurate. The very large opening allows a lot of light and thus increases the visibility of the scale. The two top screws are used to attach the meter to the panel, the bottom ones are binding posts. Horizontal reading model. *Source: Via Mr. A.E. Covington. **Similar artifacts: 1977.0020, 1977.0023, and 1977.0032.
Range: 0 to 750 microamperes.

THIS FILTER WAS PART OF THE OTTAWA RIVER SOLAR OBSERVATORY INSTALLATION. IT WAS USED ON TELESCOPE 930297, AN INSTRUMENT UNIQUE TO CANADA & THE WORLD. THE 1992 RETIREMENT OF THE ORSO SIGNIFIED THE END OF OPTICAL SOLAR PHYSICS RESEARCH AS CONDUCTED BY CDN GOV'T SCIENTISTS- AN AREA OF STUDY CONCENTRATED IN OTTAWA SINCE 1905.
USED ON SOLAR TELESCOPE AS AID IN PHOTOGRAPHY OF SPECIFIC AREA OR SPECTRUM OF PHOTOSPHERE. USED ALSO TO CONTROL PATH OF LIGHT TO MONOCHROMATOR..2 &.3 USED TO REGULATE TEMPERATURE OF FILTER.

THIS FILTER, HAVING A 1A (ANGSTROM) TO 0.5A BANDPASS, WAS PART OF THE OPTICAL ARRANGEMENT USED TO PERFORM AN H-ALPHA PATROL OF ENTIRE DISC AND OF LIMB FEATURES OF CHROMOSPHERIC MATERIAL. PHOTOGRAPHY OF THE WIDE BAND OF THE CONTINUUM WAS SIMULTANEOUS WITH THAT OF AN AREA -8+ A FROM THE H-ALPHA LINE CENTRE. (REF.2 P.4). THERMOMAT CONTROLLED TEMP. OF FILTER, A CRITICAL FACTOR
USED AT OTTAWA RIVER SOLAR OBSERVATORY SITE (ORSO), C. 20 KM WEST OF CITY CENTRE.

OUTER CASING/MOUNTING ASSEMBLY HAS FLAT BLACK FINISH; FITTED WITH WHITE SYNTHETIC ADJUSTMENT DIAL. MOST OF LENS CASING EXTERIOR HAS DIMPLE-TEXTURED MEDIUM GREY FINISH; DARK-GREY AND BLACK TRIM. TEMPERATURE & FINE ADJUSTMENT SCALES, AND LEVEL PROTECTED WITHIN GLASS ENCLOSED HOUSING.
